column27: This is the root of the phenotypic abnormality subontology of the HPO.
Root of all terms in the Human Phenotype Ontology.

column4: An abnormality of the integument, which consists of the skin and the superficial fascia.
column27: Abnormality of skin, hair, or nails.

column3: Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues
column4: An abnormality of the hematopoietic system.
column7: Haematological abnormality|Hematological abnormality|Abnormality of the haematopoietic system|Abnormality of the hematopoietic system|Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues|Hematologic disease
column27: The hematopoietic system comprises the organs that are involved in the production of blood, primarily the bone marrow, spleen, tonsils, and lymph nodes.

column4: An anomaly of the musculoskeletal system, which consists of the bones of the skeleton, muscles, cartilage, tendons, ligaments, joints, and other connective tissue. The musculoskeletal system supports the weight of the body, maintains body position and produces movements of the body or of parts of the body.
An anomaly of cellular morphology or physiology.

column27: This term describes any abnormality of the voice, i.e., of the sounds produced by humans by the passage of air through the larynx and over the vocal cords, and then modified by the resonance organs, the nasopharynx, and the mouth.

column3: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
column4: An abnormality of the fetus or the birth of the fetus, excluding structural abnormalities.
column7: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
column27: Because of the close link between prenatal developmental abnormalities and abnormalities of the birth process, a single term is chosen to subsume both classes of abnormality.

column4: The presence of any abnormality of the genitourinary system.
column7: Genitourinary tract malformation|Urogenital anomalies|Urogenital abnormalities|Genitourinary dysplasia|Genitourinary disease|Abnormality of the GU system|Genitourinary tract anomalies|Genitourinary abnormality

column4: An abnormality of the nervous system.
column7: Neurological abnormality|Abnormality of the nervous system|Brain and/or spinal cord issue|Neurologic abnormalities
column27: The nervous system comprises the neuraxis (brain, spinal cord, and ventricles), the autonomic nervous system, the enteric nervous system, and the peripheral nervous system.

Any anomaly of the digestive system, a collection of organs that is made up of the gastrointestinal tract and the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder. The gastrointestinal tract is a series of hollow organs joined in a long, twisting tube from the mouth to the anus, including the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine and anus.

column4: Any abnormality of the cardiovascular system.
column7: Cardiovascular disease|Abnormality of the cardiovascular system|Cardiovascular abnormality
column27: The cardiovascular system consists of the heart, vasculature, and the lymphatic system.

column4: An abnormality of the endocrine system.
column27: The endocrine system is composed of glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream and includes the following glands: thyroid, parathyroids, adrenals, pancreas, gonads (testicles and ovaries), and pituitary. Many other organs, such as the kidney, liver, and heart, have secondary endocrine functions.

column4: A symptom or manifestation indicating a systemic or general effect of a disease and that may affect the general well-being or status of an individual.
column27: Note that we use the preferred term label constitutional symptom because this reflects common usage, but we do not restrict the term or its descendents to the narrow meaning of symptom, i.e., a complaint related by a patient to a physician. There is no generally accepted classification of what defines a constitutional symptom, but examples include weight loss, fatigue, general weakness, night sweats, shaking, chills, fever, and vomiting.

column4: An abnormality of the respiratory system, which include the airways, lungs, and the respiratory muscles.
An abnormality of the immune system.
column7: Abnormality of the immune system|Immunological abnormality
column27: The immune system is composed of organs and interdependent cell types that collectively protect the body from infections and from the growth of tumor cells. The organs of the immune system comprise the bone marrow, the spleen, the thymus,the lymph nodes, and the cell types comprise B cells, T cells, natural killer cells, granulocytes,dendritic cells, and macrophages.

column4: Any abnormality of the eye, including location, spacing, and intraocular abnormalities.
column7: Abnormal eye|Eye disease|Abnormality of the eye

column4: An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour).
column27: The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies neoplasms into four main groups: (i) benign neoplasm, (ii) in situ neoplasm, (iii) malignant neoplasm, and (iv) neoplasm of uncertain or unknown behavior. A malignant neoplasm is also known as cancer.
Either a morphological abnormality or hearing deficit. This should be split more cleanly in the future.

column4: An abnormality of head and neck.
column7: Head and neck abnormality|Abnormality of head or neck
